Posts.Content: Viagra/Sildenafil are the same thing mostly. Viagra is the brand name, the other is the generic. Use either roughly an hour before you want to attempt an erection. Cialis is a daily dose. Take it and forget. You can also get the generic tadafil filled at a compounding pharmacy for about half price. Also, Cialis is supposed to be going over the counter towards the end of the year.

Posts.Title: Cialis, Viagra or Sildenafil for Penile Rehabilitation

Posts.Content: Viagra/Sildenafil are the same thing mostly. Viagra is the brand name, the other is the generic. Use either roughly an hour before you want to attempt an erection. Cialis is a daily dose. Take it and forget. You can also get the generic tadafil filled at a compounding pharmacy for about half price. Also, Cialis is supposed to be going over the counter towards the end of the year.

Posts.Title: Cialis, Viagra or Sildenafil for Penile Rehabilitation

Posts.Content: Winter-- Alcohol and food AFTER sildenafil has done it's work for you. 20mg would seem very light. I'd go with 60-100mg if need be. Keep in mind, you'll have more reason to perform so you might need less, then again, you're having performance anxiety already so you might need the help. If possible, chill out with no expectations on Friday evening. If she spends the night, by Saturday morning you might very well know all you need to know. --Mike

Posts.Title: Incontinence I have had enough

Posts.Content: jfredfc-- Firstly, follow Highlander's and your own advice. Secondly, apologize to your wife. I'm a year behind you on the surgery, so you've that much more time to build frustration. I also leak like an inner city fire hydrant in the summer, so take this advice as you will. You might try compression rings and see if they help. You'll have to find a balance between effectiveness and comfort. (Hint: Start large and work your way down, and double up before moving to the next smaller size. To wit; try a 9, then 8, then before moving to a 7, try the 8 and 9 together.)

Posts.Title: Cialis cost confusion?

Posts.Content: Djin-- You are right, you have a hard decision to make with three options available to you. The fact that you can't put the decision off on anyone else makes it more difficult. I know if I was in your shoes, I'd rather have the person who has studied medicine for quite a few years tell me what's best. Instead, we're left with vacuuming up huge amounts of data and trying to shoehorn our particular case into the prognosis./outcome cycles that we read about. My wife and I had a short discussion about my treatment options. With a 4+3 and a rich and storied family history with PC, my options were reduced to two. I opted for the 'damn the torpedoes, full speed ahead' approach via RALP. The idea of removing the cancerous gland appealed to me more than let's see what happens if we nuke it. The side effects from RALP, yeah, the incontinence SE is the current bane of my life at the moment. The ED seems to have mostly resolved itself by the third month post surgery. As much as I worried about ED, I really, really, wish the incontinence had resolved itself first. --Mike

For other more meaningful things, when you look at your wife, reflect on the great times you've had together, then realize that she's still there with you. If you have children, do the same. Lastly, take the time to make everyone who you encounter today feel good about the interactions they had with you. Try to curtail the normal bitching you'd do in a day. The fucker that cut you off in traffic? He didn't cut you off, you chose to let him in. 2. Make emotional love to your wife. Each and every day, make it one of your tasks to full on seduce your wife. Realize that she's seen all of your old tricks. (Some of which will still work.) Learn new ways to convince her she is making the right choice by choosing you, over all others, yet again. Take her out for a nice ($$$) dinner, or cook a nice one up at home. It's probably pretty damn cold in Northern Illinois right now. (Wait a minute, wrong line of new thinking, replace 'pretty damn cold' in that last sentence with 'delightfully brisk'.) Go for a nature walk. If she's into it, hold her hand when you walk. Remember, the goal here is to make your wife fall in love with you each day. The goal is not to keep the status quo, but to build new, stronger bonds between you two. 3. Get physically intimate, in both a non-sexual way and a sexual way. a. This builds on #2 above, but now you're touching. Every day, you had better be touching your wife. Sex. Going to avoid the details here, there's another website that's more appropriate for this. Surprisingly, not many couples have actually had an honest discussion about what they enjoy and don't enjoy. Get this out of the way. After the discussions about your fantasies, and etc., It's adult show and tell and answer time. You go first. Get cleaned up, get your pads if you still have incontinence issues, draw the curtains, and get naked. (It's a good idea to let your wife know what you're intending to do before hand.) Tell your wife everything she's ever wanted to know about your body. Explain what you feel when she does X to you. Show her where and how to touch you. Be frank, open and honest about it. When it's her turn, be sure to ask questions. Lots & lots of questions. If you are like most couples, you are generally the initiator. Have your wife pick up some of that. One way to help you and your worries about ED, is to have your wife initiate sex with you. It demonstrates that your wife desires you and is sexually interested in you. That will probably relieve a lot or your angst about ED. If you can't have erections, there's other types of sex you can have. We also added toys for each of us to our play. Posts.Content: Vince-- I'm 7 months past surgery and still leak like a sieve. Mostly dry overnight, and when seated, but as soon as I stand, I dribble, or flat out flow freely. Like you, my frustration level was/is high. I have taken to wearing a penile clip when I'm out shopping with the wife, without it I appear like someone with a case of vulgar tourettes. (Go into store, directly to men's room and pee. Feel yourself dribble as you're washing your hands, expletive, expletive.) At home, when I stand, I push my hand down my drawers and hold on until I get to the bathroom. If you are drinking *any* caffeine at all, stop. Remember that decaf still has caffeine. (I need to drop my daily 4/5 of a pot of decaf habit, down from 3 pots of full strength before surgery.) --Mike

Posts.Title: Freaking over post-op incontinence! Please tell me this gets better!

Posts.Content: Started kegels multiple times a day, 2 months prior to surgery. 2 months after surgery, I cut back to the mayo method as posted in the sticky. For the past 3 months, I'm back to multiple times a day. I walked prior to surgery, usually between 5 - 10 miles a day in moderate hilly country. I was walking the halls of the hospital the day and most of the night after surgery. After surgery I upped the walking to 10 - 15 miles a day, sometimes quite a bit further. (Have you ever walked off a few of your toe nails? I hadn't either until this fall.) I started physical therapy a few months ago. Insurance approved 30 sessions. The first 18 sessions were local and all of them involved riding a NuStep for 10 minutes, then a series of exercises aimed at improving my 'core' muscles. (Planks: facedown, faceup, sideways, on the floor, on a ball. Isolating adductor/abductor muscles against tension. Abdominal work, etc.) I stepped up and down wooden blocks. Anything the three therapists could think of to strengthen my core. They added in doing a kegel before each repetition, then during the exercises. I bought identical devices that I was using at PT for home use, except for the NuStep, for that I now have a gym membership. I use them daily. I have a strong core. Quoting RobLee: I can crack walnuts with my ass. The last 12 sessions were with a physical therapist in the next city over, one who actually possesses a certification for pelvic floor rehab. Where we also worked the core muscles, this time with the addition of a bio-feedback device glued to my butt and the treadmill replacing the NuStep. The bio-feedback device confirms that I am indeed contracting the right muscles, the lights indicating the strength is there, also I have no problem relaxing the muscles. Interestingly, with the device, I did find that while stepping backward, or doing other things that take you out of your normal comfort zone cause me to lose focus on my kegel contraction momentarily. For the last few sessions, we've switched to stretching out the pelvic floor muscles. This involves two yoga poses and a couple of minor exercises, foregoing the core building except for when I am at the PT's office so that she can observe the bio-feedback readings. Also added in to the regimen was scar tissue release. Think tummy rubs, really deep tummy rubs, which start right above your pubis bone. Lastly was diet change. Lost anything that was on a list as a bladder irritant. Who knew a banana irritated anything? I am 11 months post surgery and leak like a sieve whenever I'm standing. As Consult1 stated, this is the leaky urine that you do not even feel until it has exited your body. I can easily hold back, 400 ml or more of urine with kegel power alone until I get to the bathroom. It's the insidious leakage that you don't know about until there's not a damn thing you can do about it. My urologist does not think I am a good candidate for collagen injections and states that a urethral sling might help but, he thinks that I'm either going to eventually solve this myself or be headed for the artificial sphincter. On a side note, and possibly a contributing issue; the surgeon remarked that when he and his assistant were inserting the arms of the robot, they had a dickens of a time due to the surgical planes not being where they should have been. Apparently previous damage to my pelvic area had distorted things quite enough that it was confusing to a seasoned surgeon. (Wrecks and such what not as a child and an adult.)

Posts.Title: Poll question: post Prostatechtomy

Posts.Content: Started kegels multiple times a day, 2 months prior to surgery. 2 months after surgery, I cut back to the mayo method as posted in the sticky. For the past 3 months, I'm back to multiple times a day. I walked prior to surgery, usually between 5 - 10 miles a day in moderate hilly country. I was walking the halls of the hospital the day and most of the night after surgery. After surgery I upped the walking to 10 - 15 miles a day, sometimes quite a bit further. (Have you ever walked off a few of your toe nails? I hadn't either until this fall.) I started physical therapy a few months ago. Insurance approved 30 sessions. The first 18 sessions were local and all of them involved riding a NuStep for 10 minutes, then a series of exercises aimed at improving my 'core' muscles. (Planks: facedown, faceup, sideways, on the floor, on a ball. Isolating adductor/abductor muscles against tension. Abdominal work, etc.) I stepped up and down wooden blocks. Anything the three therapists could think of to strengthen my core. They added in doing a kegel before each repetition, then during the exercises. I bought identical devices that I was using at PT for home use, except for the NuStep, for that I now have a gym membership. I use them daily. I have a strong core. Quoting RobLee: I can crack walnuts with my ass. The last 12 sessions were with a physical therapist in the next city over, one who actually possesses a certification for pelvic floor rehab. Where we also worked the core muscles, this time with the addition of a bio-feedback device glued to my butt and the treadmill replacing the NuStep. The bio-feedback device confirms that I am indeed contracting the right muscles, the lights indicating the strength is there, also I have no problem relaxing the muscles. Interestingly, with the device, I did find that while stepping backward, or doing other things that take you out of your normal comfort zone cause me to lose focus on my kegel contraction momentarily. For the last few sessions, we've switched to stretching out the pelvic floor muscles. This involves two yoga poses and a couple of minor exercises, foregoing the core building except for when I am at the PT's office so that she can observe the bio-feedback readings. Also added in to the regimen was scar tissue release. Think tummy rubs, really deep tummy rubs, which start right above your pubis bone. Lastly was diet change. Lost anything that was on a list as a bladder irritant. Who knew a banana irritated anything? I am 11 months post surgery and leak like a sieve whenever I'm standing. As Consult1 stated, this is the leaky urine that you do not even feel until it has exited your body. I can easily hold back, 400 ml or more of urine with kegel power alone until I get to the bathroom. It's the insidious leakage that you don't know about until there's not a damn thing you can do about it. My urologist does not think I am a good candidate for collagen injections and states that a urethral sling might help but, he thinks that I'm either going to eventually solve this myself or be headed for the artificial sphincter. On a side note, and possibly a contributing issue; the surgeon remarked that when he and his assistant were inserting the arms of the robot, they had a dickens of a time due to the surgical planes not being where they should have been. Apparently previous damage to my pelvic area had distorted things quite enough that it was confusing to a seasoned surgeon. (Wrecks and such what not as a child and an adult.)

Posts.Content: I'm currently taking PT for my incontinence issue. (New definition of 'Wet Willy'.) The therapist has put me on the biofeedback machine (STR-10) which helps show me how my pelvic floor muscles are performing with the kegels. This has been enormously helpful the three times I have tried it. Monday I'm due to try out an electrical stimulator device. (Ride 'em cowboy!) This will probably be the STM-10 device. With a prescription I can rent/buy the devices, but since my insurance is quite lame, it might be better economically if I can buy the used machines. (Not the probe or patches, though.) I understand that E-Stim shows no improvement over manual kegels after 8 weeks, but I'd sure like to give it a try. PM me, if you have a used device to sell for a reasonable price. --Mike

Posts.Content: You might want to look at belted pads/pullups for changing in public restrooms. Just unbutton, clean up and put on new dry one. Pants need go no further down than mid thigh. Personally, I didn't like them as they seemed warmer to me than briefs, but that might have been due to the brands used.
Posts.Title: Depends pads and briefs?

Posts.Content: Ok. I've been on a few walks. They let me walk alone now but the Nurse has to unclip the IV. I had the note to get extra catheter straps, but didn't think about it on the first walk -- no travel bag yet... Needless to say, the tube itself creates quite the impression on you when the straps leave you thigh and drop to your ankles. Fixed that by pulling the straps back up and holding them, then I noticed something warm and soft hitting my knees. Since I was just worked on in that area, I thought for a minute that they forgot to get rid of something... Turns out it was the belly drainage bulb. Now I have the catheter hose glued on and I put the bulb in the robe pocket. Getting ready to do breathin exercises and take the last walk of the night. Trying to get out of here tomorrow afternoon. --Mike

Posts.Title: Catheter is out!

Posts.Content: Consult-- The sweat pants should have an elastic band around the ankles. That will hold up an empty/ mostly empty bed bag. If you're comfortable with doing so you can swap out the bed bag with a leg bag and use the straps on your calf, then it's simply lift the lid, aim away from your sock and let fly. Then close valve, dab with toilet paper and go back out 'normal like'. This allows you to wear loose fitting normal trousers. Also, if you have a canvas shopping bag, they are good to make your bag a little more incognito if you don't go with the sweat pants. Also, you might want a robe unless you trust the hospital gown to stay tied while you're walking around the hospital. --Mike

Posts.Title: PSA results are in, not great news, but totally expected

Posts.Content: bpc-- Your biopsy looks very similar to mine. My PSA was higher at 5.13, I had three cores at 3+3=6 and one at 4+3=7. Like you, the three 3+3's on the right and the 4+3 on the left base. I went with RALP. For me 3 month PSA, it came back <.01, will be having the 6 month PSA draw soon. I am still having issues with incontinence. I leak like a sieve. The ED does not seem to be an issue for me. (Taking 5mg of cialis daily.) No matter which route you end up choosing, start working on your kegel exercises in earnest. --Mike

Posts.Title: First Post, Struggling to Stay Positive

Posts.Content: RobLee-- You're 4 or 5 months my senior on the RP. I'm not tracking well on the incontinence either. I thought between doing kegels since my diagnosis, and my generally good health, the incontinence would be easily conquered. I thought wrong. I'm seriously disappointed that I haven't had a pad free moment since surgery unless it's in the bathroom. So, while I can't comment on the AUS, it is definitely in the back of my mind. It would be nice not to have to walk from where I'm sitting to the bathroom without having a hand on my dick to keep from flooding yet another pad. I'm sure you are also frustrated with this one: Urinate in the toilet, take your time, push, pull, twist and anything else that can possibly get another drop out. Then take 3 steps to the right to wash your hands and feel yourself pissing. Everyone asks about her, how she's doing. She has no hair, so it's like a badge of honor. Meanwhile I have to drag this "ball and chain" (leg bag and condom catheter) everywhere I go... even sleep with it, or I piss all over. I think it's starting to get to me. I think as a society we've been programmed to protect women and children. Men? Well, man up dude. We hear and see this all the time. Take two obits for a male and female involved in a fatal accident. "Mrs Smith was a loving mother of 3..." and "Mr Smith, a former railroad employee..." I also think we men reject empathy for ourselves due the the man up principle. I know I certainly repeated all the positive things, such as they are, that I had heard about this disease. --Mike

Posts.Title: First Post, Struggling to Stay Positive

Posts.Content: Drake-- There will be a regimen to follow: Basically you'll create vacuum to enlarge your penis, hold the vacuum for a while then repeat the process. Usually, 15 to 30 mins. Caveats: If you're still incontinent, you'll have to watch the urine levels in the tube. Avoid getting urine in the pump. If need be, buy a water based VED. Lube the tube before use, otherwise the skin will stick to the side of the tube and get quite painful. Don't overdo the pressure. The pump is stronger than you think and can rupture things. Pump as long as it's comfortable. If it gets painful, you're overdoing it and need to back the pressure off. --Mike

Posts.Title: Where will you be for the eclipse?

Posts.Content: Dear Members of the Zero Club, I received my first PSA results today after having Da Vinci surgery in January. The results are 'PSA <0.01'. I think you accept slight rounding errors. I'm stoked and ready to become a member of this 'Zero Club'. I know I joined the PCa club not too long ago, but I would much prefer to be in this shiny new club. The only negative I know about that having me join the club is I'm apt to dribble a tad on the floors, unless I've had coffee, in which case it's quite a bit more than a tad. I will volunteer to carry a mop and bucket while on the premises though. I await your responses. PS; No more hazing. That PCa club had some pretty brutal hazing to it. Thanks in advance! --Mike

Posts.Title: Surgery is done tpjames wife reporting

Posts.Content: On the ED thing, I apparently follow my father in that I get a shot of ED before PC. (The things you discuss with your mother now a days...) Taking my cue from some of the members, I did get my urologist to hand out Viagra samples and prescribe sildenafil before surgery with the intent to stock up. I've been testing the effectiveness (for science!) of both. (Can't beat the $10 for 30 tabs of 20mg sildenafil at Sams for plus members.)

Posts.Title: Wife's Chemo is finally over !!!

Posts.Content: Sawdust-- The VED elongates and fills your penis via vacuum. If you're considering one there are two main types. Wet and Dry. You take the wet type into the shower with you. It gets filled with water, then yourself. If you're still rather incontinent, this is the way to go as it's used to working wet anyway. I do NOT have the wet type. If you go with the dry, you're also going to need to lube the tube. If you don't, your penis will bind on the side of the tube and painfully make some rather interesting shapes. This also brings up something else, whatever you get, make sure it has an EMERGENCY RELEASE BUTTON. Side note: Remember the good ol' magic trick that involved a peeled boiled egg getting sucked, virtually unscathed, into an old fashioned milk bottle by the vacuum left by cooling air from an extinguished match? When the VED is substituting for the bottle and one of your testicles becomes the substitute for the egg, this is one of the reasons for the emergency release button. In addition to therapy, you can use the VED to inflate your penis enough to get you a semi woody for penetration. Once inflated, you put a retention ring to hold the blood in your penis and then you have a stuffable penis for awhile. Note: Due to the fact that the blood brought back into the penis is held there by a retention ring, your penis will be get cool and be slightly discolored. The Viberect is a vibrator for men. I have NOT used the viberect. What it does is vibrate your penis at a specified frequency and is supposed to help you orgasm. In combination with the ED drugs you've been prescribed, it should tirelessly provide the stimulus your penis needs in order for the drugs to do their job of getting the blood there. Since you're taking Cialis this is an anytime thing. I do use a different toy to help in the orgasm department. That toy vibrates a pad that you locate near or on your frenulum. It is waterproof, you can just drop it in your pullups. As others have noted here on these boards, your new 'Orgasm 2.0' will be rather different than before. I find mine (with the toy) to be MUCH more intense that what I had prior to the prostatectomy. You can involve your significant other with either of these devices. They can help you with the VED, or they can use the vibrator on or with you. I bought my wife a toy at the same time I bought mine. Fair is fair, right? Using them on each other usually works well and has the desired results. Left to our own devices, (Heh!), the toys usually run less than two minutes. If you have an interest you can PM me and I will tell you brand names on the VED and toys we use, otherwise I'll not advertise. --Mike

Posts.Title: Walking/Exercise Post Surgery

Posts.Content: Mark-- I have an air type pump. I bought it prior to surgery in anticipation of needing it. I have NOT used the water based pumps. As Highlander said, it can be somewhat painful, usually that is the result of getting a bit too aggressive on the pump. From everything I had read, the best results seemed to come from the air based pumps by men using them in one or two 30 minutes sessions. Surprisingly you will need lube to use an air pump. Without lube, little Mark will have a tendency to get firmly stuck on the side of the tube, while the rest keeps inflating. This is another source of pain, and also brings up the reason for having an emergency release button on the device. Another source of pain is when one or both of your nuts attempt to join the fun. Again, the emergency release button is important. Your device should provide a shield to help mitigate this and to generally help in providing a seal. Whatever pump you get (if any), you're going to need to get a compression ring onto the base of your penis. As Highlander stated, deflation happens quickly. The pump I got came with a set of compression rings, numbered 3 (smallest) to 9. They all look small, you'll have a tendency to go bigger than you need. Trial and error here. Remember that once you manage to stuff it in, a vagina, being a pretty strong muscle, is actively going to be undoing your inflation bit. Smaller compression ring. The pump I have has a twist mechanism to slide a ring off the tube and onto your penis. In fact it can handle two rings at the same time. So, prior to surgery, while I did have some partial ED I found a 7 ring worked well. After surgery notes: I can get some time in the saddle so to speak, but apparently I'm still working on the appropriate ring size now with complete ED. The 7 ring was a complete and literal let down. Second and very important note, incontinence is a bitch and doesn't add much to the awkward romantic settings that we try and set up. But an important note none the less. With an air pump, the pump is not expecting to handle liquid. If you still have control issues like me, you're going to get to experience a wet pump anyway, it just won't be water. You'll have to keep the pump pointed up to keep the urine from entering the pump while maintaining suction. Remember, at some point you're going to want to impress you're partner with what you're going to pull out of that tube? You had better make your way to the bathroom before breaking the vacuum connection, if not, you'd both better be into water sports. To wrap this up, if you are not getting erections any other way, do use a pump, it will help to stretch your penis. Keep in mind that you can stretch your penis by hand. If you go the pump route, be prepared to have a few failures for various reasons first. --Mike

Posts.Content: As a follow on From the Revision statement at the bottom of the document Michael F. referenced. On 1 May 2016, these changes were made. Revision; updated description, added medical necessity criteria for: benign or malignant conditions involving the base of the skull or axial skeleton, left breast tumors, lung cancer, malignant lesions of liver, peri-diaphragmatic cancer, unresectable extremity sarcoma, unresectable retroperitoneal sarcoma, and upper abdominal cancer; added medical necessity position statement and criteria for prostate cancer, added comparative effectiveness analysis statement and flowchart; added comparative effective analysis statement for proton beam therapy for the treatment of prostate cancer, updated ICD-10 codes; updated program exception; added LOINC codes; updated references. I could not find a previous copy of the document.

Posts.Title: Am I making the right choice?

Posts.Content: RAD-- Just for clarity, let's separate two terms: orgasm and erection, as either can be accomplished independent of the other. You asked about orgasms. You should be able to achieve orgasms now. It's more difficult without an erection but it should be manageable manually or with a little help from electronics. The Viberect, can be prescribed by your Dr. This gizmo uses vibrations to stimulate you to orgasm. I DO NOT OWN NOR HAVE I TRIED THE VIBERECT. Another device is an egg shaped gizmo that you lay your penis in and it then stimulates your frenulum vigorously and brings you to orgasm. Works on an erect or flaccid penis. I DO HAVE THIS. PM me for the name if interested. Then there's the manual method that most of us mastered as teenagers. You can use a pump to help give yourself a little more to work with or not. I find the restriction rings used to keep the erection dampen the feeling from my penis which requires a little faster stimulation by hand. In any event, while waiting for things to get back to normal, you can have orgasms. They will most likely be absolutely dry orgasms and they will be different. In my case, they are far more intense and have a longer duration. Good luck. --Mike

Posts.Title: The Drive Home

Posts.Content: Jagle-- As Chuck mentioned, the procedure takes about 15 mins for the 12 core biopsy. The process: You'll be given a prescription for an antibiotic that you'll take before and after the biopsy. You'll undress and get in a gown. Then you'll most likely lay on your side (some men are on their back in stirrups), with your butt almost off the table, knees drawn up towards your chest. Your doctor at this point may numb your anus. If you want this done, make sure you ask the Dr to do so, before your appointment so they can have it ready. (Also, you could ask for a calming pill of sorts.) The Dr will then insert a really, really, really, well lubed probe up your rectum. The probe will stay there the entire time. The Dr will move drugs and cores in and out through the probe. The probe has ultra sound and the Dr will use this to find your prostate. You'll get a shot or two of lidocaine to your rectum. If you haven't had any other pain meds, you'll feel this. Not near as intense as a shot to the back of the mouth at the dentists, but more like a little sting. You'll get several shots of lidocaine to your prostate. Again not painful per se, but you will feel this. The Dr will then (assuming a standard 12 core biopsy) pull a 3 row, 4 column grid of core samples from your prostate. For each core, you'll likely feel some pressure for about 1-2 seconds as the needle is inserted, then you'll hear a loud snap as the core is pulled. In my case, I felt each core as the needle was inserted. To me is was sharp, but bearable. My wife says that my eyes went wide each time. After the biopsy, you'll be seated upright and given a chance to clean up. If you bring a light weight feminine pad that will help keep your underwear from getting messy. (Or just make judicious use of the Dr's paper towels. You'll wait a week to get your biopsy results. Your urine might show blood for a bit. Mine was a very light pinkish color the day of the biopsy, not noticeable after that. Your ejaculate will show blood for a bit also. Lets just say you'll have full sympathy, if you don't already, for the fairer sex's monthly issues. Mine cleared up in less than a week with daily ejaculations. In any event, as far as pain goes, the biopsy will probably not be the worst thing you'll have felt. Probably not in the top ten. --Mike

Posts.Content: BeIll-- Welcome to the forum. Glad you found us. The first thing you'll want to do is get a physical copy of your biopsy pathology report. It will list the details about each core sample. Where on the prostate the core was taken, how long the sample was; and on your 7's, whether it was a 3+4=7 or a 4+3=7. You'll also want to look at the sticky towards the top of this forum regarding how to edit/update your forum signature. Then you can put the info about family history, PSA/DRE tests and pathology into a signature and not be asked about it. They say that things slow down here on the weekends, but there will be several very well read people coming along with some questions and excellent advice. --Mike

Posts.Title: Second Biopsy After ASAP on First

Posts.Content: Jagle-- As Chuck mentioned, the procedure takes about 15 mins for the 12 core biopsy. The process: You'll be given a prescription for an antibiotic that you'll take before and after the biopsy. You'll undress and get in a gown. Then you'll most likely lay on your side (some men are on their back in stirrups), with your butt almost off the table, knees drawn up towards your chest. Your doctor at this point may numb your anus. If you want this done, make sure you ask the Dr to do so, before your appointment so they can have it ready. (Also, you could ask for a calming pill of sorts.) The Dr will then insert a really, really, really, well lubed probe up your rectum. The probe will stay there the entire time. The Dr will move drugs and cores in and out through the probe. The probe has ultra sound and the Dr will use this to find your prostate. You'll get a shot or two of lidocaine to your rectum. If you haven't had any other pain meds, you'll feel this. Not near as intense as a shot to the back of the mouth at the dentists, but more like a little sting. You'll get several shots of lidocaine to your prostate. Again not painful per se, but you will feel this. The Dr will then (assuming a standard 12 core biopsy) pull a 3 row, 4 column grid of core samples from your prostate. For each core, you'll likely feel some pressure for about 1-2 seconds as the needle is inserted, then you'll hear a loud snap as the core is pulled. In my case, I felt each core as the needle was inserted. To me is was sharp, but bearable. My wife says that my eyes went wide each time. After the biopsy, you'll be seated upright and given a chance to clean up. If you bring a light weight feminine pad that will help keep your underwear from getting messy. (Or just make judicious use of the Dr's paper towels. You'll wait a week to get your biopsy results. Your urine might show blood for a bit. Mine was a very light pinkish color the day of the biopsy, not noticeable after that. Your ejaculate will show blood for a bit also. Lets just say you'll have full sympathy, if you don't already, for the fairer sex's monthly issues. Mine cleared up in less than a week with daily ejaculations. In any event, as far as pain goes, the biopsy will probably not be the worst thing you'll have felt. Probably not in the top ten. --Mike

Posts.Title: prostate biopsy due to sudden elevated PSA

Posts.Content: PDV-- On the knee replacement thing, make sure to do your rehab exercises. You get one chance to work the knee to the fullest range of motion that you can stand. Any range of motion for the knee that you don't do while in rehab is a range you're not going to have later w/o some pretty rough follow on surgery. Source? Wife that always follows instructions (and has a high pain tolerance), sister that doesn't. --Mike

Posts.Content: Robert-- I imagine he's feeling bitter about getting cancer and reflecting that outward. Some more info might help. Is he the older brother? Only one to get prostate cancer in the family? Was his treatment successful? Are you sure? How about side effects? Is he continent? Has he come bounced back from ED? Both side effect can be emasculating if not worked through.

Posts.Title: Five years in the zero club

Posts.Content: The two major side effects of prostate surgery are immediate. You then recover from them. Your surgeon will probably be able to save your nerves and your erections will return sooner that you think. As for incontinence, practice your kegels, stay fit and healthy and like most men you should recover from that issue (at least mostly) within a year or so. Good luck on this.

Posts.Title: I really did not want to be in this club.

Posts.Content: Hello fellow PCa warriors! I was more than happy to be ostracized by you guys, seriously, I was. I realize that you guys were also happy not to have me in the club. And yet...here I am, a neophyte, joining the club. I am sure I will have questions. Still wrapping my head around the whole PC thing. I'm glad to have some knowledgeable people that I can ask questions when I have them. From what I've seen, you guys (and gals) have been forthright and frank in your answers, and have managed to build a very supportive community here. I have DaVinci surgery scheduled for early January. So until then, I'll be practicing Kegels and learning more. Just thought I'd officially say "Hi.". I also understand that since I'm now in this club, I should be aspiring to become a member in good standing of the "Zero Club"? Does my signature need to have anything added or deleted? --Mike

Posts.Title: Pinched "hose"

Posts.Content: Hello fellow PCa warriors! I was more than happy to be ostracized by you guys, seriously, I was. I realize that you guys were also happy not to have me in the club. And yet...here I am, a neophyte, joining the club. I am sure I will have questions. Still wrapping my head around the whole PC thing. I'm glad to have some knowledgeable people that I can ask questions when I have them. From what I've seen, you guys (and gals) have been forthright and frank in your answers, and have managed to build a very supportive community here. I have DaVinci surgery scheduled for early January. So until then, I'll be practicing Kegels and learning more. Just thought I'd officially say "Hi.". I also understand that since I'm now in this club, I should be aspiring to become a member in good standing of the "Zero Club"? Does my signature need to have anything added or deleted? --Mike

Posts.Content: Just a note on the Vasoline: Some sites say it it okay to use and even go as far as to suggest Vasoline as a lubricant for the Foley catheter. Other sites make the case that Vasoline, due to being petroleum based, can damage the catheter. In one study, the effects of 4 different lubes were tried on Foley catheters over the period of 5 days. Each lube was tested with 20 catheters each. At the end of 5 days, there were 20 catheter balloon ruptures, all of them involved the catheters where the Vasoline was used.

Posts.Title: Very Sensitive Urethra, Apparently

Posts.Content: 4th time in a row (18 months) PSA < 0.01. Still incontinent. Have tried kegels; few (Mayo sticky), many. Worked with physical therapist with certs in pelvic floor. Built up my core. Have done scar management. Bladder friendly diet. Lost weight. Amped up walking to at least 10+ miles a day. Did bio-feedback, tried electro. Took two different drugs to try and tame the bladder. Nothing has worked to date. Now looking at the AMS-800. For those with an AMS-800, would you do it again? Are you dry? Down to one pad? ED has returned to pre RALP levels.

Posts.Title: New Member of the "0" Club!!!!

Posts.Content: I saw a highly recommended urologist locally (E David Crawford). He ordered a urine test called Select MDX. The result of that test was VERY LOW RISK. It said I indicate a 98% probability that I have PC with a Gleason greater than 7 and 99% for Gleason greater than 8. This all seems like very good news. My follow up is next Wed. Chris, something is off on your statement. You say VERY LOW RISK, which would be good, then you say "I indicate a 98% probability that I have PC with a Gleason greater than 7 and 99% for Gleason greater than 8" which would be bad. Did you mean less than Gleason 7 or 8?

Posts.Title: PSA vs. uPSA

Posts.Content: Jagle-- As Chuck mentioned, the procedure takes about 15 mins for the 12 core biopsy. The process: You'll be given a prescription for an antibiotic that you'll take before and after the biopsy. You'll undress and get in a gown. Then you'll most likely lay on your side (some men are on their back in stirrups), with your butt almost off the table, knees drawn up towards your chest. Your doctor at this point may numb your anus. If you want this done, make sure you ask the Dr to do so, before your appointment so they can have it ready. (Also, you could ask for a calming pill of sorts.) The Dr will then insert a really, really, really, well lubed probe up your rectum. The probe will stay there the entire time. The Dr will move drugs and cores in and out through the probe. The probe has ultra sound and the Dr will use this to find your prostate. You'll get a shot or two of lidocaine to your rectum. If you haven't had any other pain meds, you'll feel this. Not near as intense as a shot to the back of the mouth at the dentists, but more like a little sting. You'll get several shots of lidocaine to your prostate. Again not painful per se, but you will feel this. The Dr will then (assuming a standard 12 core biopsy) pull a 3 row, 4 column grid of core samples from your prostate. For each core, you'll likely feel some pressure for about 1-2 seconds as the needle is inserted, then you'll hear a loud snap as the core is pulled. In my case, I felt each core as the needle was inserted. To me is was sharp, but bearable. My wife says that my eyes went wide each time. After the biopsy, you'll be seated upright and given a chance to clean up. If you bring a light weight feminine pad that will help keep your underwear from getting messy. (Or just make judicious use of the Dr's paper towels. You'll wait a week to get your biopsy results. Your urine might show blood for a bit. Mine was a very light pinkish color the day of the biopsy, not noticeable after that. Your ejaculate will show blood for a bit also. Lets just say you'll have full sympathy, if you don't already, for the fairer sex's monthly issues. Mine cleared up in less than a week with daily ejaculations. In any event, as far as pain goes, the biopsy will probably not be the worst thing you'll have felt. Probably not in the top ten. --Mike

Posts.Title: 10 months after 2 questions

Posts.Content: Jim-- Thanks for the reminder: Every guy has a different time frame for reaching full continence. And, over and over, we have seen instances when a patient sees more leakage one day than the preceding day and they become depressed and start feeling sorry for themselves because "...it's not getting better, it's getting worse AND this is ONLY happening to me..." when, in fact, it is simply normal and part of the healing process. I don't get depressed and feel sorry for myself, instead I get, wait for it, ... pissed. For me, this is the most difficult part so far. I haven't pissed myself since I came out of diapers the first time. Now? Just call me "Drippin Dan", "Leaky Larry" or "Wet Willy". With that off my chest and out of the way, I do see improvement. So I'm okay with it so far. --Mike

Posts.Title: Another New Guy question

Posts.Content: Pottk-- This link is chock full of stuff, and covers the full gamut. You won't need a lot of it, but some you definitely will: https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...-Vinci-surgery I just got home from surgery, here's my usages so far: Pre-surgery: .Antibacterial soap for showers .Stool softener (It's cumulative, you want it working before your surgery) Surgery: .Lip balm (You're pretty dry) .Lozenges (Coughing hurts and you've had a pipe down your throat) .Lidocaine gel (Ask your Dr, it needs a prescription; put this on the catheter tube and the tip of your penis) .A Robe for your walks around the hospital .Slippers (Easier on your feet than the non-slip socks while walking) Release Day: .Stretch pants (Go up a size, you'll be pretty full of gas and you'll need to accomodate your catheter) .Looser top (You're going to be sore, make it easy on yourself) Post-surgery, Catheter Week: .Paper towels (To catch urine leakage when on the pot, remember you've got a hose connected) .Small bucket (To hold and carry your catheter bag, just in case, you didn't close the bag, the bucket will catch the spill) .Canvas shopping bag (To carry your catheter bag discretely) --Mike

Posts.Title: Sex 3 to 5 years after radiotherapy.

Posts.Content: Pottk-- This link is chock full of stuff, and covers the full gamut. You won't need a lot of it, but some you definitely will: https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...-Vinci-surgery I just got home from surgery, here's my usages so far: Pre-surgery: .Antibacterial soap for showers .Stool softener (It's cumulative, you want it working before your surgery) Surgery: .Lip balm (You're pretty dry) .Lozenges (Coughing hurts and you've had a pipe down your throat) .Lidocaine gel (Ask your Dr, it needs a prescription; put this on the catheter tube and the tip of your penis) .A Robe for your walks around the hospital .Slippers (Easier on your feet than the non-slip socks while walking) Release Day: .Stretch pants (Go up a size, you'll be pretty full of gas and you'll need to accomodate your catheter) .Looser top (You're going to be sore, make it easy on yourself) Post-surgery, Catheter Week: .Paper towels (To catch urine leakage when on the pot, remember you've got a hose connected) .Small bucket (To hold and carry your catheter bag, just in case, you didn't close the bag, the bucket will catch the spill) .Canvas shopping bag (To carry your catheter bag discretely) --Mike

Posts.Title: Prostrate cancer

Posts.Content: I'm thinking the Chinese dinner might have had a bit more salt than you're used to in your diet, causing you to retain water? This site: https://prostatecancerinfolink.net/t...nical-staging/ Says: Note: An older form of the TNM staging system included a stage known as stage T3c disease that was eliminated in more recent updates to this staging system. And on page 2 of this link: http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/1...cncr.21632/pdf There's a handy chart showing when t3c was used and when it was phased out.

Posts.Title: Around another corner

Posts.Content: Kitkat/DH-- I am just 6 months past RALP. I am still incontinent, but think I am seeing improvement. On the ED, I think I'm progressing nicely. Caveat: I do take 5mg Cialis daily. Currently, I can get the start of an erection just thinking 'nice' thoughts. A little stimulation and I'm good to go for a short while. For a longer duration, I have to have some help from sildenafil, but to be fair, that was true before RALP also. Best wishes no matter what route you pursue. --Mike

Posts.Content: 1. RALP 2. Biopsied with a 4+3=7 Gleason score and a solid family history of PCa, went with RALP keeping radiation as a backup if needed. 3. Surgery went well, stayed an extra day in the hospital due to not passing gas. So far, one year out from RALP, PSA is holding at <0.01. As for side effects, I'm incontinent, but have no problems with erections.
